revision.text:
[[File:Cycladic pan FKII BLM 75-11.jpg|thumb|Underside of the ''Cycladian frying pan'' 75/11]] The '''Cycladian frying pan''' (formerly Karlsruhe, Badisches Landesmuseum, inventory number 75/11) is an ornately decorated stone object from the [[Bronze Age]] [[Cycladic civilization]]. It dates to the Early Cycladic period, between the 27th and 24th centuries BC (EC II). The find spot is unknown, except that it originated on the [[Cyclades|Cycladic island]] of [[Naxos]]. The item derived from an [[Grave robbery|illegal excavation]] and was acquired in 1975 by the [[Badisches Landesmuseum]] in [[Karlsruhe]]. On 6 June 2014 it was [[Art repatriation|repatriated]] to the [[National Archaeological Museum, Athens|National Archaeological Museum]] of [[Athens]], [[Greece]].
== Description == The frying pan is a round dish with a diameter of 17.5 cm and a depth of 2.8 cm. There is a 2.2 cm long handle in the shape of a pie slice. It is made from [[greenschist]], which derives from the Cycladic island of Naxos.<ref name=blm2011-307>Claus Hattler (Ed.): ''Kykladen - Lebenswelten einer frühgriechischen Kultur''. Primus Verlag, Darmstadt 2011, {{ISBN|978-3-86312-016-0}}, p. 307.</ref>
The front side, with a flat bottom and narrow, recessed edge, is undecorated. It is the back side which makes the object stand out. This surface is surrounded by a [[Chip carving|chip]] patterned band, even on the handle. The area inside this band is filled with a pattern of interwoven spirals. A single large spiral in the centre is connected by double strands to seven medium-sized spirals surrounding it. These seven spirals are surrounded by an outer row of fourteen yet smaller spirals. Each of the seven medium spirals are connected to two of their neighbours and to three of the spirals in the outer row. The spirals on the outer edge are each connected to their two neighbours and are formed of three or four spirals, depending on whether they are linked to one or two of the medium-sized spirals. On the handle, double and triple strands form a crisscross pattern with triangles.<ref name=blm1976-517>Jürgen Thimme (Ed.): ''Kunst und Kultur der Kykladeninseln im 3. Jahrtausend vor Christus.'' C. F. Müller 1976, {{ISBN|3-7880-9568-7}}, p. 517.</ref>
The outer surface of the bowl is a bit weathered, slightly knocked and has a few scratches on it. On the inside there are flecks of [[Calcareous sinter|sinter]]; a thick layer of sinter was removed from the decorated back side in modern times, revealing the patterns now visible.<ref name=blm1976-517 />
[[File:Pyxis, Cycladic, 2700-2300 BC, AS Berlin Misc. 8102, 144352.jpg|thumb|[[Lidded pyxis with spiral decoration|Lidded pyxis]] with similar spiral pattern, [[Antikensammlung Berlin]]]] Patterns of interlocking spirals are often incised in Cycladic pottery, but in stone they are found on only a few items, particularly [[pyxis|pyxides]]. An example was discovered in excavations on the island of [[Amorgos]] and acquired for the [[Antikensammlung Berlin]] by [[Georg Ferdinand Dümmler]].<ref>Staatliche Museen zu Berlin, Antikensammlung, [http://www.smb-digital.de/eMuseumPlus?service=ExternalInterface&module=collection&objectId=694886&viewType=detailView Inv. Misc. 8102] (Link to the digital collection of the Staatliche Museen in Berlin, with image)</ref> The quality of the work and the very carefully executed pattern ought to be attributed to an experienced and especially talented artisan. The frying pan must have been a prominent prestige object for its owner.<ref name=blm2011-307 />
In the [[Keros-Syros culture|Keros-Syros phase]] of the Cycladic civilization, to which this piece is attributed, ceramic frying pans are very common. In addition a very few are known which are made out of marble. But the only other example made out of stone is an undecorated example first published by [[Nikolaos M. Kontoleon]] in 1972.<ref name=blm1976-102>Pat Getz-Preziosi, ''Frühkykladische Steingefäße''. in Jürgen Thimme (Ed.): ''Kunst und Kultur der Kykladeninseln im 3. Jahrtausend vor Christus.'' C. F. Müller, Karlsruhe 1976, {{ISBN|3-7880-9568-7}}, pp. 97–110, 102.</ref> This frying pan is thus unique in material and execution and is therefore seen as a "masterpiece of Cycladic art." <ref>{{cite journal|author=John E. Coleman |title="Frying Pans" of the Early Bronze Age Aegean|journal=American Journal of Archaeology|volume= 89|number =2|year=1985|page=211}}</ref>
== Purpose == The use and purpose of Cycladic frying pans is unclear. They are mostly known as grave goods in especially rich graves. [[Christos Tsountas]] originally suggested that they were mirrors. According to him, the flat bowl would have been filled with water and the user would have been able to see their reflection in them.<ref name=blm1976-102 /> Experiments do not support this theory, since water does not produce a mirror effect and, while olive oil does work it is believed to have been too rare and expensive for this purpose in the early Cycladic period.<ref name=blm2011-100ff>Bernhard Steinmann, ''Spiegel oder Spendenschale?'' in Claus Hattler (ed.), ''Kykladen - Lebenswelten einer frühgriechischen Kultur''. Primus Verlag, Darmstadt 2011, {{ISBN|978-3-86312-016-0}}, pp. 100–107.</ref>
On account of several finds in the cemetery of Chalandriani on the island of [[Syros]] and small examples of clay and bone with paint residue, Nikolaos M. Kontoleon suggested that they could have been [[Palette (painting)|palette]]s for the creation of paints from crushed pigments.<ref name=blm1976-102 />
The decoration of the frying pans recall water, almost without exception. Spirals, ships and stars are usual. The ceramic frying pans often have two handles, projecting from the body with a women's genitals incised in the triangular space between them. On account of this, it has been suggested that they received [[libation]]s in some kind of [[fertility rite]];<ref name=blm2011-307 /> sea, Sun and femininity may have been seen as symbols of the fertility of the body and the sea, which was essential for human life.<ref name=blm2011-100ff />
A further possibility was raised by [[Christos Doumas]] in 1993, who suggested that they were used to process [[sea salt]]. Doumas connected the issue of trade and exchange of goods before the invention of money with this, proposing that salt might have served as a valuable material, while leaving no archaeologically detectable traces.<ref name=blm2011-100ff />
== Provenance == In 1975, in the lead up to the 1976 exhibition ''"Kunst der Kykladen"'' (Art of the Cyclades), the then curator of the Badisches Landesmuseum, [[Jürgen Thimme]], bought the frying pan from an art dealer for 35,000 [[German Mark|marks]]<ref>Südwestrundfunk: [http://www.swr.de/swr2/programm/sendungen/kontext/illegaler-handel-mit-antiker-kunst/-/id=4352076/did=13290156/nid=4352076/179yfxz/index.html Kriminelle Archäologie: Warum fast der komplette Handel mit antiker Kunst illegal ist]. SWR2, broadcast of 6 June 2014.</ref> along with a female [[Cycladic figurine (Karlsruhe 75/49)]] and other artefacts. The frying pan did not derive from a legal excavation, but the vendor guaranteed that the object had been acquired before 1970, although he offered no evidence and remained anonymous. In any case, an illegal excavation violated Greek law and the object could only have been removed from the country by smuggling. But since the original acquisition took place before 1970, the [[UNESCO]] ''Convention for the Banning and Prevention of Illegal Import, Export and Sale of Cultural Artefacts'' enacted in 1970 would not have been violated and the purchase would have been legal under international law. In addition, the German Republic only signed the convention in 2007.
The exhibition in the Karlsruhe Schloss in 1976 featured by far the widest collection of Cycladic objects displayed up till that time. In accord with the then prevailing view in Museum circles and with the support of the [[International Council of Museums]]<ref>[[Ernst Petrasch]], "Zur Ausstellung," in Thimme, 1976 p. 6</ref> loans from international museums and a number of private collections were displayed without scrutinising their provenance.<ref name=blm1976-517 /> The Greek antiquities department objected to this at the time of the exhibition first being publicised and therefore refused to make any pieces from their state collections available for the exhibition. However, the then leader of the [[Ephorate for Prehistoric and Classical Antiquities|antiquities department of the Cyclades]], Christos Doumas wrote the chapter for the exhibition catalogue on the archaeological exploration of Cycladic culture and spoke in it about graverobbing.<ref>Christos Doumas, "Die archäologische Erforschung der frühen Bronzezeit auf den Kykladen," in Jürgen Thimme (Ed.): ''Kunst und Kultur der Kykladeninseln im 3. Jahrtausend vor Christus''. C. F. Müller, Karlsruhe 1976, {{ISBN|3-7880-9568-7}}, pp. 190–197.</ref>
After Germany acceded to the UNESCO convention in 2007, museums found themselves in a problematic situation - especially the Badische Landesmuseum. In their second great international exhibition in 2011, ''Kykladen - Lebenswelten einer frühgriechischen Kultur'' (Cyclades - Life-world of an Early Greek Culture), the Landesmuseum specifically identified the provenance of the exhibits and displayed only objects from national and international collection which disclosed the origin of the pieces. Objects from private collections were not displayed. But the Greek authorities were not satisfied with their handling of the issues and again refused to loan items.<ref>Harald Siebenmorgen, "Vorwort" in Claus Hattler (Ed.), ''Kykladen - Lebenswelten einer frühgriechischen Kultur''. Primus Verlag 2011, {{ISBN|978-3-86312-016-0}}, pp. 6–9, 7.</ref>
Long negotiations followed and on 6 June 2014, the frying pan, along with figurine 75/49 were returned to the [[National Archaeological Museum of Athens]] by the State Secretary of the Baden-Württemberg Ministry of Scholarship, Research & Art, [[Harald Siebenmorgen]], in the company of the Greek Minister of Culture [[Panagiotis Panagiotopoulos]]. The current value of the frying pan has been estimated to lie in the millions of [[Euro]]s.<ref>[http://www.baden-wuerttemberg.de/de/service/presse/pressemitteilung/pid/rueckgabe-von-raubgrabkunst-an-griechenland/ Pressemitteilung: Rückgabe von Raubgrabkunst an Griechenland] Ministerium für Wissenschaft, Forschung und Kunst, Baden-Württemberg, 6. Juni 2014</ref>
== Bibliography == *{{Cite book|editor=[[Jürgen Thimme]]|title=Kunst und Kultur der Kykladeninseln im 3. Jahrtausend vor Christus|publisher = C. F. Müller, Karlsruhe |year=1976|pages=338, 517; No. 364|ISBN=3-7880-9568-7}} *{{Cite journal|author=John E. Coleman |title="Frying Pans" of the Early Bronze Age Aegean|journal=American Journal of Archaeology|volume= 89|number =2|year=1985|pages=191–219|doi=10.2307/504325}}
== References == {{reflist}}

Removing link(s) to "VideoGamer.com": rm link(s) to deleted article. ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
{{Distinguish|Guinness World Records#Gamer's edition{{!}} Guinness World Records: Gamer's Edition}} {{Infobox video game | title = Guinness World Records: The Videogame | image = Guinness World Records-The Video Game.jpg | caption = North American [[Wii]] cover for ''Guinness World Records: The Videogame'' | developer = [[TT Fusion]] | publisher = [[Warner Bros. Interactive Entertainment]] | platforms = {{Unbulleted list|[[iOS]]|[[Nintendo DS]]|[[Wii]]}} | released = '''Wii, Nintendo DS'''{{Video game release|PAL|November 7, 2008|NA|November 11, 2008}}'''iOS'''{{Video game release|WW|June 1, 2009}} | genre = [[Party video game|Party]] | modes = [[Single-player video game|Single-player]], [[Multiplayer video game|multiplayer]] }} '''''Guinness World Records: The Videogame''''' is a [[Party video game|party]] [[video game]] based on the [[Guinness World Records]] series of books of world records. Developed by [[TT Fusion]] and published by [[Warner Bros. Interactive Entertainment]], the game was released on November 7, 2008 in Europe and Australasia, and on November 11, 2008 in North America. The game involves attempting to beat real-life world records through minigames. The game saw mixed to positive reviews upon release, and was considered better than most minigame compilations that were on [[Nintendo]] consoles at the time. == Gameplay == ''Guinness World Records: The Videogame'' contains 36 mini-games based on real-world record attempts. The player can select 12 avatars, and can travel around a globe- like map that allows them to select minigames. Beating minigames allows the player to unlock more minigames and outfits for their avatars. Minigames involve attempting to beat a world record as fast as possible, such as building the highest skyscraper in a [[Tetris]] style minigame, attempting the world's highest [[BMX]] stunt jump, and eating a [[jumbo jet]] as fast as possible. The player's score is placed on a scoreboard at the end of the round, and is then compared over the internet to other player's scores. The game shows trivia about real-life world records on the menu and during loading screens.{{Cite web |url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/guinness-world-records-the-videogame-review?page=2 |title=Guinness World Records: The Videogame Review |publisher=[[Eurogamer]] |last=Parkin |first=Simon |date=19 December 2008 |accessdate=26 December 2017}}{{cite web|last1=DiMola|first1=Franchesca|title=Guinness World Records: The Videogame- review|url=http://www.nintendoworldreport.com/review/17508/guinness-world-records-the-videogame-wii|website=Nintendo World Report|publisher=NINWR|accessdate=10 April 2018}} == Reception == {{Video game reviews | GR = DS: 70.00%
Wii: 67.50% | MC = DS: 70/100
Wii: 67/100 | VG = 8/10{{Cite web |url=https://www.videogamer.com/reviews/guinness-world-records-the-videogame-review |title=Guinness World Records: The Videogame Review |publisher=VideoGamer.com |last=Orry |first=Tom |date=26 November 2008 |accessdate=26 December 2017}} | EuroG = 7/10{{Cite web |url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/guinness-world-records-the-videogame-review?page=2 |title=Guinness World Records: The Videogame Review |publisher=[[Eurogamer]] |last=Parkin |first=Simon |date=19 December 2008 |accessdate=26 December 2017}} | IGN = 7/10{{Cite web |url=http://wii.ign.com/articles/932/932458p1.html |title=IGN: Guinness World Records: The Videogame Review |publisher=[[IGN]] |last=Thomas |first=Lucas M. |date=20 November 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081216025539/http://wii.ign.com/articles/932/932458p1.html |archivedate=16 December 2008 |accessdate=26 December 2017}} }} ''Guinness World Records: The Videogame'' received mixed reviews from critics upon release. On [[Metacritic]], the game holds scores of 70/100 for the [[Nintendo DS]] version based on 4 reviews{{Cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/ds/guinness-world-records-the-videogame |title=Guinness World Records: The Videogame for DS Reviews |publisher=[[Metacritic]] |accessdate=26 December 2017}}, and 67/100 for the Wii version based on 12 reviews.{{Cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/wii/guinness-world-records-the-videogame |title=Guinness World Records: The Videogame for Wii Reviews |publisher=[[Metacritic]] |accessdate=26 December 2017}} On [[GameRankings]], the game holds scores of 70.00% for the DS version based on 4 reviews{{Cite web |url=http://www.gamerankings.com/ds/952523-guinness-world-records-the-videogame/index.html |title=Guinness World Records: The Videogame for DS |publisher=[[GameRankings]] |accessdate=26 December 2017}}, and 67.50% for the [[Wii]] version based on 16 reviews.{{Cite web |url=http://www.gamerankings.com/wii/952524-guinness-world-records-the-videogame/index.html |title=Guinness World Records: The Videogame for Wii |publisher=[[GameRankings]] |accessdate=26 December 2017}} Reviewing the DS and Wii version for [[IGN]], Mark Thomas praised the games strange minigames, comparing it positively to [[Warioware]], before ending the review with, "[...] But even then there are a couple of more fully-fledged gems in this pack that are addictive enough to warrant keeping the game handy long after you've been declared the best, the tallest, the strongest and the smartest with every record there is.".{{Cite web |url=http://wii.ign.com/articles/932/932458p1.html |title=IGN: Guinness World Records: The Videogame Review |publisher=[[IGN]] |last=Thomas |first=Lucas M. |date=20 November 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081216025539/http://wii.ign.com/articles/932/932458p1.html |archivedate=16 December 2008 |accessdate=26 December 2017}} Writing for [[Nintendo World Report]] and reviewing both versions, Francesca DiMola found the games lack of similarity to actual World Records disappointing and the games boring, saying, "The lack of identity and direction is unfulfilling, and while a select group of mini-games are entertaining and original, many of them feel generic and bland.".{{cite web|last1=DiMola|first1=Franchesca|title=Guinness World Records: The Videogame- review|url=http://www.nintendoworldreport.com/review/17508/guinness-world-records-the-videogame-wii|website=Nintendo World Report|publisher=NINWR|accessdate=10 April 2018}} Writing for [[Eurogamer]] and reviewing the Wii version, Simon Parkin found the idea to be interesting, ending the review with "[...] Guinness World Records is the best mini-game collection we've played on the Wii, in part because of the content but principally because of its context."{{Cite web |url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/guinness-world-records-the-videogame-review?page=2 |title=Guinness World Records: The Videogame Review |publisher=[[Eurogamer]] |last=Parkin |first=Simon |date=19 December 2008 |accessdate=26 December 2017}} == External links == *[http://www.mobygames.com/game/nintendo-ds/guinness-world-records-the-videogame Guinness World Records: The Videogame] at [[Mobygames]] == References == {{Reflist}} [[Category:2008 video games]] [[Category:Guinness World Records]] [[Category:IOS games]] [[Category:Nintendo DS games]] [[Category:Nintendo Wi-Fi Connection games]] [[Category:Video games developed in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Warner Bros. Interactive Entertainment games]] [[Category:Wii games]] [[Category:Wii Wi-Fi games]]

revision.text:
{{Unreferenced|date=December 2009}} '''Implicational hierarchy''', in [[linguistics]], is a chain of implicational [[linguistic universal|universals]]. A set of chained universals is schematically shown as in (1): (1) '''A < B < C < D''' It can be reformulated in the following way: If a language has property D, then it also has properties A, B, and C; if a language has a property C, then it also has properties A and B, etc. In other words, the implicational hierarchy defines the possible combinations of properties A, B, C, and D as listed in matrix (2): {| class="wikitable" ! width="50"| ||width="25"|A||width="25"|B||width="25"|C||width="25"|D |- | Type 1: || align='center'|+ || align='center'|+ ||align='center'|+ ||align='center'|+ |- | Type 2: || align='center'|+ || align='center'|+ ||align='center'|+ ||align='center'|- |- | Type 3: || align='center'|+ || align='center'|+ ||align='center'|- ||align='center'|- |- | Type 4: || align='center'|+ || align='center'|- ||align='center'|- ||align='center'|- |- | Type 5: || align='center'|- || align='center'|- ||align='center'|- ||align='center'|- |} Implicational hierarchies are a useful tool in capturing linguistic generalizations pertaining the different components of the language. They are found in all subfields of grammar. ==Phonology== (3) is an example of an implicational hierarchy concerning the distribution of nasal phonemes across languages, which concerns dental/alveolar, bilabial, and palatal voiced nasals, respectively: (3) '''{{IPA|/n/}} < {{IPA|/m/}} < {{IPA|/ɲ/}}''' This hierarchy defines the following possible combinations of dental/alveolar, bilabial, and palatal voiced nasals in the phoneme inventory of a language: (4) {| class="wikitable" ! width="50"| ||width="30"|{{IPA|/n/}} ||width="30"|{{IPA|/m/}}||width="30"|{{IPA|/ɲ/}} |- | Type 1: || align='center'|{{IPA|/n/}} || align='center'|{{IPA|/m/}} ||align='center'|{{IPA|/ɲ/}} |- | Type 2: || align='center'|{{IPA|/n/}} || align='center'|{{IPA|/m/}} || align='center'|- |- | Type 3: || align='center'|{{IPA|/n/}} || align='center'|- ||align='center'|- |} In other words, the hierarchy implies that there are no languages with {{IPA|/ɲ/}} but without {{IPA|/m/}} and {{IPA|/n/}}, or with {{IPA|/ɲ/}} and {{IPA|/m/}} but without {{IPA|/n/}}. ==Morphology== [[grammatical number|Number]] marking provides an example of implicational hierarchies in morphology. (5) '''Number: singular < plural < dual < trial / paucal''' On the one hand, the hierarchy implies that no language distinguishes a trial unless having a dual, and no language has dual without a plural. On the other hand, the hierarchy provides implications for the morphological marking: if the plural is coded with a certain number of morphemes, then the dual is coded with at least as many morphemes. ==Syntax== Implicational hierarchies also play a role in syntactic phenomena. For instance, in some languages (e.g. [[Tangut people|Tangut]]) the transitive verb agrees not with a subject, or the object, but with the syntactic argument which is higher on the person hierarchy. (5) '''Person: first < second < third'''
See also: [[animacy]]. ==Bibliography== * Comrie, B. (1989). ''Language universals and linguistic typology: Syntax and morphology.'' Oxford: Blackwell, 2nd edn. * Croft, W. (1990). ''Typology and universals''. Cambridge: Cambridge UP. * Whaley, L.J. (1997). ''Introduction to typology: The unity and diversity of language.'' Newbury Park: Sage. {{DEFAULTSORT:Implicational Hierarchy}} [[Category:Linguistic typology]]

{{cleanup rewrite|date=January 2010}} ''See also: [[Isaac Asimov bibliography (categorical)]], [[Isaac Asimov bibliography (chronological)]]''
The goal of this article is to present a complete [[bibliography]] of the books written or edited by [[Isaac Asimov]], arranged alphabetically.<ref name=book>[http://www.asimovonline.com/oldsite/asimov_catalogue.html "A Catalogue of Isaac Asimov's Books."] ''www.asimovonline.com.'' Retrieved November 10, 2017.</ref> Since Asimov is one of the most prolific authors of all time{{citation needed|date=November 2016}}, and since he engaged in many collaborations with other authors, this is a substantial research project. This list may not yet be complete. The total number of books listed here is over 500. Asimov died in 1992 at age 72. A small number of these books were published posthumously.
See also [[Isaac Asimov book series bibliography]], [[Isaac Asimov short stories bibliography]].
{{compact ToC|side=yes|top=yes|num=yes}}__NOTOC__
==A== * ABC's of Ecology * ABC's of Space * ABC's of the Earth * ABC's of the Ocean * [[Adding a Dimension]] * [[All the Troubles of the World]] * Alpha Centauri, the Nearest Star * [[The Alternate Asimovs]] * Amazing Stories: Sixty Years of the Best Science Fiction<ref>Astonishing Stories 2/40</ref> * Ancient Astronomy * Animals of the Bible * The Annotated 'Gulliver's Travels' * The Asimov Chronicles * Asimov Laughs Again * Asimov on Astronomy * Asimov on Chemistry * Asimov on Numbers * Asimov on Physics * Asimov on Science * [[Asimov on Science Fiction]] * Asimov's Annotated 'Don Juan' * Asimov's Annotated Gilbert and Sullivan * Asimov's Annotated 'Paradise Lost' * [[Asimov's Biographical Encyclopedia of Science and Technology]] * Asimov's Biographical Encyclopedia of Science and Technology, 2D Ed. * Asimov's Biographical Encyclopedia of Science and Technology, 3D Ed. * Asimov's Chronology of Science and Discovery * [[Asimov's Chronology of the World]] * Asimov's Galaxy: Reflections on Science Fiction * Asimov's Guide to Halley's Comet * [[Asimov's Guide to Science]] * [[Asimov's Guide to Shakespeare]], Volume One * [[Asimov's Guide to Shakespeare]], Volume Two * [[Asimov's Guide to the Bible|Asimov's Guide to the Bible, Volume One]] * [[Asimov's Guide to the Bible|Asimov's Guide to the Bible, Volume Two]] * [[Asimov's Mysteries]] * [[Asimov's New Guide to Science]] * Asimov's Sherlockian Limericks * The Asteroids * Astronomy Today * [[Atlantis (anthology)|Atlantis]] * [[Atom: Journey Across the Subatomic Cosmos]] * Authorised Murder (Originally published as [[Murder at the ABA]]) * [[Azazel (Asimov)|Azazel]] (1988)
==B== * Baker's Dozen: Thirteen Short Fantasy Novels * Baker's Dozen: Thirteen Short Science Fiction Novels * [[Banquets of the Black Widowers]] * [[Before the Golden Age]] * The Beginning and the End * Beginnings: The Story of Origins, of Mankind, Life, the Earth, the Universe * The Best Mysteries of Isaac Asimov * The Best New Thing * [[The Best of Isaac Asimov]] * [[The Best Science Fiction of Isaac Asimov]] * [[The Bicentennial Man and Other Stories]] * The Big Apple Mysteries * Biochemistry and Human Metabolism * The Birth and Death of Stars * The Birth of the United States, 1763–1816 * Breakthroughs in Science * [[Building Blocks of the Universe]] * [[Buy Jupiter and Other Stories]]
==C== [[File:Galaxy 195310.jpg|thumb|right|The first installment of Asimov's ''The Caves of Steel'' took the cover of the October 1953 issue of ''[[Galaxy Science Fiction]]'', illustrated by [[Ed Emshwiller]]]] * [[Cal (short story)|Cal]] ''See also [[Robot series (Asimov)|''Robot'' series (Asimov)]]'' * [[Casebook of the Black Widowers]] * Catastrophes! * Caught in the Organ Draft * [[The Caves of Steel]] (1954), ''See also [[Robot series (Asimov)|''Robot'' series (Asimov)]]'' * Change! * The Chemicals of Life * Chemistry and Human Health * Child of Time (with [[Robert Silverberg]], UK title of ''The Ugly Little Boy'') * [[A Choice of Catastrophes]]<ref>[http://www.asimovreviews.net/Books/Book207.html "Review: ''A Choice of Catastrophes.''"] ''www.asimovreviews.net.'' Retrieved November 10, 2017.</ref><ref>[http://www.goodreads.com/book/show/1891139.A_Choice_of_Catastrophes "Review: ''A Choice of Catastrophes.''"] ''www.goodreads.com.'' Retrieved November 10, 2017.</ref> * Christopher Columbus: Navigator to the New World * The Clock We Live on * The Collapsing Universe * Colonizing the Planets and Stars * [[Comets (anthology)|Comets]] * Comets and Meteors * [[The Complete Robot]] (1982), ''See also [[Robot series (Asimov)|''Robot'' series (Asimov)]]'' * The Complete Science Fair Handbook * [[The Complete Stories (Asimov)|The Complete Stories Vol. 1]] * [[The Complete Stories (Asimov)|The Complete Stories Vol. 2]] * Computer Crimes and Capers * Constantinople, the Forgotten Empire * Cosmic Critiques: How and Why Ten Science Fiction Stories Work * [[Cosmic Knights]] * [[Counting the Eons]] * Creations * [[The Currents of Space]] * [[Curses (anthology)|Curses]]
==D== * The Dangers of Intelligence and Other Essays * The Dark Ages * [[David Starr, Space Ranger]] (as [[Isaac Asimov|Paul French]]) * [[The Death Dealers]] (later republished as ''A Whiff of Death'') * [[Devils (anthology)|Devils]] * Did Comets Kill the Dinosaurs? * [[The Disappearing Man and Other Mysteries]] * The Double Planet * Dragon Tales * The Dream, Benjamin's Dream & Benjamin's Bicentennial Blast
==E== * [[The Early Asimov]] * [[Earth Is Room Enough]] * Earth: Our Crowded Spaceship * Earth: Our Home Base * The Earth's Moon * An Easy Introduction to the Slide Rule * The Edge of Tomorrow * The Egyptians * Election Day 2084: Science Fiction Stories on the Politics of the Future (edited by Isaac Asimov and [[Martin H. Greenberg]]) * Electricity and Man * Encounters * [[The End of Eternity]] * The Ends of the Earth * Environments Out There * The Evitable Conflict * The Exploding Suns * [[Exploring the Earth and the Cosmos]] * Extraterrestrial Civilizations * Eyes on the Universe
==F== * [[Fact and Fancy]] * [[Faeries (anthology)|Faeries]] * Familiar Poems, Annotated * Fantastic Creatures * Fantastic Reading: Stories and Activities for Grades 5–8 * [[Fantastic Voyage]] * [[Fantastic Voyage II: Destination Brain]] * [[Far as Human Eye Could See]] * Ferdinand Magellan: Opening the Door to World Exploration * [[Fifty Short Science Fiction Tales]] * Flying Saucers * [[Forward the Foundation]] * [[Foundation (Isaac Asimov novel)|Foundation]] * [[Foundation and Earth]] * [[Foundation and Empire]] * [[Foundation's Edge]] * [[Franchise (Asimov)|Franchise]] * [[From Earth to Heaven]] * Frontiers II: More Recent Discoveries about Life, Earth, Space, and the Universe * Frontiers: New Discoveries about Man and His Planet, Outer Space and the Universe (essays originally published in The Los Angeles Times) * The Future I (with [[Martin H. Greenberg]] and Charles G. Waugh) * The Future in Question * The Future in Space * ''Futuredays: A Nineteenth Century Vision of the Year 2000'' (1986) (based on [[En L'An 2000]])
==G== * Galaxies * The Genetic Code * The Genetic Effects of Radiation * [[Ghosts (anthology)|Ghosts]] * [[Giants (anthology)|Giants]] * Ginn Science Program (Advanced A, Advanced B, Intermediate A, Intermediate B, Intermediate C) * [[The Gods Themselves]] * [[Gold (Asimov)|Gold]] * The Golden Door: The United States from 1865 to 1918 * [[Good Taste]] * Great Ideas of Science * Great Science Fiction Stories by the World's Great Scientists * The Greeks: A Great Adventure * A Grossery of Limericks (with John Ciardi)

revision.text:
{{good article}} [[File:Antique_Konya_Kilim_detail_labelled.jpg|thumb|350px|Detail of [[vegetable dye|vegetable-dyed]] [[Konya]] Kilim, numbered to identify motifs:

  1) Eye ({{lang-tr|Göz|links=no}}) / [[Evil eye|Evil Eye]] ({{lang-tr|Nazarlık|links=no}})
  2) Eye, containing Cross ({{lang-tr|Haç|links=no}})
  3) Ram's Horn ({{lang-tr|Koçboynuzu|links=no}})
  4) Fertility ({{lang-tr|Bereket|links=no}})
  5) Wolf's Mouth ({{lang-tr|Kurt İzi|links=no}})
  6) Star ({{lang-tr|Yıldız|links=no}}), containing [[Yin/Yang|Love and Unison]] ({{lang-tr|Aşk ve Birleşim|links=no}})
  7) Star, containing Fetter ({{lang-tr|Bukaǧı|links=no}})]] {{Use British English|date=February 2017}} Many '''motifs''' are used in traditional '''[[kilims]]''', handmade flat-woven rugs, each with many variations. In Turkish [[Anatolia]] in particular, village women wove themes significant for their lives into their rugs, whether before marriage or during married life. Some motifs represent desires, such as for happiness and children; others, for protection against threats such as wolves (to the flocks) and scorpions, or against the [[evil eye]]. These motifs were often combined when woven into patterns on kilims. With the fading of tribal and village cultures in the 20th century, the meaning of kilim patterns has faded also. In these tribal societies, women wove kilims at different stages of their lives, choosing themes appropriate to their own circumstances. Some of the motifs used are widespread across Anatolia and sometimes across other regions of West Asia, but patterns vary between tribes and villages, and rugs often expressed personal and social meaning. ==Context== [[File:Kilim slit weave.jpg|thumb|upright|Diagram of Kilim slit weave technique, showing how the weft threads of each colour are wound back from the colour boundary, leaving a slit]] {{main|Kilim}} A Turkish [[kilim]] is a flat-woven rug from [[Anatolia]]. Although the name kilim is sometimes used loosely in the West to include all type of rug such as cicim, palaz, soumak and zili, in fact any type other than pile [[carpet]]s, the name kilim properly denotes a specific weaving technique. Cicim, palaz, [[soumak]] and zili are made using three groups of threads, namely longitudinal warps, crossing wefts, and wrapping coloured threads. The wrapping threads give these rugs additional thickness and strength. Kilim in contrast are woven flat, using only warp and weft threads. Kilim patterns are created by winding the weft threads, which are coloured, backwards and forwards around pairs of warp threads, leaving the resulting weave completely flat. Kilim are therefore called flatweave or flatware rugs.{{cite book |author=Erbek, Güran |title=Kilim Catalogue No. 1 |publisher =May Selçuk A. S. |edition=1st |date=1998 |pages=4–30}} To create a sharp pattern, weavers usually end each pattern element at a particular thread, winding the coloured weft threads back around the same warps, leaving a narrow gap or slit. These are prized by collectors for the crispness of their decoration. The motifs on kilims woven in this way are constrained to be somewhat angular and geometric.{{cite book | last=Davies | first=Peter | year=2000 | title=The Visual Language of the Anatolian Kilim |work=Antique kilims of Anatolia | publisher=[[W.W. Norton & Co.]] | isbn=978-0-393-73047-0 | pages=Chapter 5 and passim}} In tribal societies, kilim were woven by women at different stages of their lives: before marriage, in readiness for married life; while married, for her children; and finally, kilim for her own funeral, to be given to the mosque. Kilims thus had strong personal and social significance in tribal and village cultures, being made for personal and family use. Feelings of happiness or sorrow, hopes and fears were expressed in the weaving motifs. Many of these represent familiar household and personal objects, such as a hairband, a comb, an earring, a trousseau chest, a jug, a hook.{{cite web |last1=Taskiran |first1=Nurdan |title=Reading Motifs on Kilims: A Semiological Approach to Symbolic Meaning |url=http://docplayer.net/24199186-Reading-motifs-on-kilims-a-semiological-approach-to-symbolic-meaning.html |publisher=Yeditepe.edu.tr |accessdate=22 January 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171029093031/http://docplayer.net/24199186-Reading-motifs-on-kilims-a-semiological-approach-to-symbolic-meaning.html |archivedate=29 October 2017 |pages=1–12}} ==Meanings== [[File:Elibelinde2.svg|thumb|left|The ''{{lang|tr|[[Elibelinde]]}}'' or hands-on-hips motif is a stylized female figure, symbolizing motherhood and [[fertility]].]] The meanings expressed in kilims derive both from the individual motifs used, and by their pattern and arrangement in the rug as a whole. A few symbols are widespread across Anatolia as well as other regions including [[Persia]] and the Caucasus; others are confined to Anatolia.{{cite web |title=Carpet Motifs: A Beginner's Guide |url=http://www.arastan.com/journey/carpet-motifs-beginners-guide |publisher=Arastan |accessdate=22 January 2016 |date=9 May 2012}} An especially widely used motif is the ''{{lang|tr|[[Elibelinde]]}}'', a stylized female figure, symbolizing motherhood and [[fertility]].{{cite web | url=http://www.kilim.com/about_kilims/motifs/hands_on_hips.asp | title=Hands on Hips - Elibelinde | accessdate=24 February 2014}}{{cite web |last1=Unal |first1=Sahika |title=Symbolic Meanings and Characteristics of Anatolian Kilims |url=http://www.crystallography.fr/mathcryst/pdf/istanbul/Unal.pdf |accessdate=22 January 2016 |date=August 2009}} Other motifs express the tribal weavers' desires for protection of their families' flocks from wolves with the wolf's mouth or the wolf's foot motif ({{lang-tr|Kurt Aǧzi, Kurt İzi}}), or for safety from the sting of the [[scorpion]] ({{lang-tr|Akrep|links=no}}). Several protective motifs, such as those for the [[dragon]] ({{lang-tr|Ejder|links=no}}), scorpion, and spider (sometimes called the crab or tortoise by carpet specialists) share the same basic diamond shape with a hooked or stepped boundary, often making them very difficult to distinguish.{{cite book |last1=Anquetil |first1=Jacques |title=Carpets Techniques Traditions and History |date=2003 |publisher=Hachette |isbn=978-1-84430-012-9 |pages=40–43}} Several motifs hope for the safety of the weaver's family from the [[evil eye]] ({{lang-tr|Nazarlık|links=no}}, also used as a motif), which could be divided into four with a cross symbol ({{lang-tr|Haç|links=no}}), or averted with the symbol of a hook ({{lang-tr|Çengel|links=no}}), a human eye ({{lang-tr|Göz|links=no}}), or an [[amulet]] ({{lang-tr|Muska|links=no}}; often, a triangular package containing a sacred verse).{{cite web |title=Kilim Motifs |url=https://www.kilim.com/kilim-wiki/kilim-motifs |publisher=Kilim.com |accessdate=22 January 2016}} The carpet expert Jon Thompson explains that such an amulet woven into a rug is not a theme: to the weaver, it actually is an amulet, conferring protection by its presence. In his words, to people in the village and tribal cultures that wove kilims, "the device in the rug has a materiality, it generates a field of force able to interact with other unseen forces and is not merely an intellectual abstraction."{{cite book |last1=Thompson |first1=Jon |title=Carpets from the Tents, Cottages and Workshops of Asia |date=1988 |publisher=Barrie & Jenkins |isbn=0-7126-2501-1 |page=156}} [[File:Azeri carpet (Sirvan group).jpg|thumb|upright=1.2|Similar motifs are sometimes used in pile carpets, such as the rows of Solomon's seal stars, rows of hooks, ram's horns, and elibelinde motifs in this [[Shirvan]] carpet from Azerbaijan.]] Other motifs symbolised fertility, as with the [[trousseau chest]] motif ({{lang-tr|Sandıklı|links=no}}), or the explicit fertility ({{lang-tr|Bereket|links=no}}) motif. The motif for running water ({{lang-tr|Su Yolu|links=no}}) similarly depicts the resource literally. The desire to tie a family or lovers together could be depicted with a [[fetter]] motif ({{lang-tr|Bukaǧı|links=no}}). Similarly, a tombstone motif may indicate not simply death, but the desire to die rather than to part from the beloved. Several motifs represented the desire for good luck and happiness, as for instance the bird ({{lang-tr|Kuş|links=no}}) and the star or [[Polygonatum|Solomon's seal]] ({{lang-tr|Yıldız|links=no}}). The oriental symbol of [[Yin/Yang]] is used for love and unison ({{lang-tr|Aşk ve Birleşim|links=no}}). Among the motifs used late in life, the [[Tree of Life]] ({{lang-tr|Hayat Aǧacı|links=no}}) symbolizes the desire for immortality. Many of the plants used to represent the Tree of Life can also be seen as symbols of fruitfulness, fertility, and abundance. Thus the [[pomegranate]], a tree whose fruits carry many seeds, implies the desire for many children. Symbols are often combined, as when the feminine elibelinde and the masculine ram's horn are each drawn twice, overlapping at the centre, forming a figure (some variants of the ''{{lang|tr|Bereket}}'' or fertility motif) of the sacred union of the principles of the sexes.{{cite web |last1=Özyurt |first1=Üzeyir |title=The Language of Kilim of Anatolia |url=http://www.dervishbrothers.com/kilimsymbology/Kilimingilizce.pdf |publisher=Dervish Brothers |accessdate=22 January 2016}} ==Motifs== All the motifs can vary considerably in appearance according to the weaver. Colours, sizes and shapes can all be chosen according to taste and the tradition in a given village or tribe; further, motifs are often combined, as illustrated in the photographs above. To give some idea of this variability, a few alternative forms are shown in the table. {| class="wikitable sortable" |+ Kilim motifs and their meanings ! Name !! Turkish !! Motif !! Purpose !! Object !! Notes |- | Hands-on-hips motif || {{lang|tr|[[Elibelinde]]}} || [[File:Elibelinde2.jpg|120px]] || Motherhood,
[[fertility]] || Marriage || Female principle (4 examples) |- | [[Cross]] motif || {{lang|tr|Haç}} || [[File:Cross Kilim Motif.jpg|80px]] || Protection || [[Evil eye]] || to divide the evil eye into four
(2 examples) |- | [[Hook]] motif || {{lang|tr|Çengel}} || [[File:Hook Kilim Motif.jpg|30px]] || Protection || [[Evil eye]] ||to destroy the evil eye |- | [[Eye]] motif || {{lang|tr|Göz}} || [[File:Eye Kilim Motif.jpg|120px]] || Protection || [[Evil eye]] ||to ward off the evil eye
(3 examples) |- | [[Comb]] motif || {{lang|tr|Tarak}} || [[File:Comb Kilim Motif.jpg|80px]] || Protection || Birth,
marriage || May also symbolise rain, water of life
(2 examples) |- | Running [[water]] motif || {{lang|tr|Su Yolu}} || [[File:Running Water Kilim Motif.jpg|80px]] || Fresh water || Life || very important in tribal life
(3 examples) |- | [[Fertility]] motif || {{lang|tr|Bereket}} || [[File:Fertility Kilim Motif.jpg|120px]] || Fertility || Marriage || Combines female principle (hands-on-hips), male principle (ram's horn)
(2 examples) |- | [[Sheep|Ram]]'s [[horn (anatomy)|horn]] motif || {{lang|tr|Koçboynuzu}} || [[File:Ram's Horn Kilim Motif.jpg|120px]] || Fertility,
Power,
Masculinity || Marriage || Male principle (2 examples) |- | [[Star]] motif || {{lang|tr|Yıldız}} || [[File:Star Kilim Motif.jpg|80px]] || Fertility,
happiness || Marriage || [[Polygonatum|Solomon's seal]], a white starlike flower |- | [[Love|Love and Unison]] motif || {{lang|tr|Aşk ve Birleşim}} || [[File:Love and Unison Kilim Motif.jpg|60px]] || Love and harmony || Marriage ||Derived from oriental
[[Yin/Yang]] motif [[File:Taijitu - Small (CW).svg|16px]] |- | [[Amulet]] motif || {{lang|tr|Muska}} || [[File:Amulet Kilim Motif.jpg|120px]] || Protection
Luck || [[Evil eye]] || Amulets worn on the person contained a verse of scripture
sewn into a square of cloth folded into a triangle. (3 examples) |- | [[Bird]] motif || {{lang|tr|Kuş}} || [[File:Bird Kilim Motif, for luck and happiness, etc.jpg|120px]] || Luck,
Happiness,
strength || Life || [[Owl]] and [[raven]] signify bad luck;
[[pigeon]] and [[nightingale]], good luck.
Also [[soul]]s of the dead; expectation of news.
(2 examples){{cite web|title=Bird - Kus |url=https://www.kilim.com/kilim-wiki/kilim-motifs/bird|publisher=Kilim.com|accessdate=23 January 2016}} |- | [[Fetter]] motif || {{lang|tr|Bukaǧı}} || [[File:Fetter Kilim Motif.jpg|50px]] || Union || Marriage || To tie family or lovers together.
The fetter tied front and hind legs of a goat. |- | [[Trousseau chest]] motif || {{lang|tr|Sandıklı}} || [[File:Trousseau Chest Kilim Motif.jpg|80px]] || Marriage,
children|| Marriage ||Unmarried women prepared [[dowry]] in a chest. |- | [[Earring]] motif || {{lang|tr|Küpe}} || [[File:Earring Kilim Motif.jpg|80px]] || Marriage || — || A common wedding present |- | [[Wolf]]'s Mouth motif
Wolf's Track motif || {{lang|tr|Kurt Aǧzi}},
{{lang|tr|Kurt İzi}} || [[File:Wolf's Mouth Kilim Motif.jpg|120px]] || Protection of the flocks || [[Wolf|Wolves]] ||(2 examples) |- | [[Scorpion]] motif || {{lang|tr|Akrep}} || [[File:Scorpion kilim motif.jpg|120px]] || Protection || [[Scorpion]]s ||(2 examples). Similar motifs are used for other
animals such as [[Spider]], [[Crab]] and Dragon. |- | [[Dragon]] motif || {{lang|tr|Ejder}} || [[File:Dragon Kilim Motif.jpg|120px]] || Protection? || - || Dragon is "master of air and water",
cause of lunar eclipse, guard of treasure.
(4 examples) |- | [[Tree of life]] motif ||{{lang|tr| Hayat Aǧacı}} || [[File:Tree of Life Kilim Motif.jpg|50px]] || Immortality || - ||Many different plants may be represented,
e.g., beech, cypress, fig, oak,
olive, palm, pomegranate, vine |- | [[Burdock]] motif || {{lang|tr|Pitrak}} || [[File:Burdock Kilim Motifs.jpg|120px]] || Protection,
abundance || [[Evil eye]] || Plant is used to ward off evil eye.
With many flowers, it symbolizes abundance. |} ==See also== * [[Islamic geometric patterns]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://arastan.com/journey/border-motifs-in-oriental-carpets Border motifs in oriental carpets] {{Islamic art}} {{Rugs and carpets}} [[Category:Textiles in mythology and folklore]] [[Category:Turkish culture]]

revision.comment: Moving from [[Category:Computer benchmarks]] to [[Category:Benchmarks (computing)]] per [[Wikipedia:Categories for discussion/Speed]] using [[c:Help:Cat-a-lot|Cat-a-lot]]
revision.text:
{{Other uses|LINPACK (disambiguation)}}
{{Infobox software | name = Linpack benchmarks | title = LINPACK benchmarks | logo = <!-- [[File:]] --> | screenshot = <!-- [[File:]] --> | caption = | collapsible = | author = [[Jack Dongarra]], Jim Bunch, [[Cleve Moler]], and Gilbert Stewart | developer = | released = {{Start date|1979}} | discontinued = | latest release version = | latest release date = <!-- {{Start date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|df=yes/no}} --> | latest preview version = | latest preview date = <!-- {{Start date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|df=yes/no}} --> | frequently updated = <!-- DO NOT include this parameter unless you know what it does --> | programming language = | operating system = | platform = | size = | language = | status = | genre = | license = | website = {{URL|http://www.netlib.org/benchmark/hpl/}} }}
The '''LINPACK [[Benchmark (computing)|Benchmarks]]''' are a measure of a system's [[floating point]] computing power. Introduced by [[Jack Dongarra]], they measure how fast a computer solves a dense ''n'' by ''n'' [[system of linear equations]] ''Ax'' = ''b'', which is a common task in [[engineering]].
The latest version of these benchmarks is used to build the [[TOP500]] list, ranking the world's most powerful supercomputers.<ref name="top500"/>
The aim is to approximate how fast a computer will perform when solving real problems. It is a simplification, since no single computational task can reflect the overall performance of a computer system. Nevertheless, the LINPACK benchmark performance can provide a good correction over the peak performance provided by the manufacturer. The peak performance is the maximal theoretical performance a computer can achieve, calculated as the machine's frequency, in cycles per second, times the number of operations per cycle it can perform. The actual performance will always be lower than the peak performance.<ref name="hplpaper"/> The [[Computer performance|performance of a computer]] is a complex issue that depends on many interconnected variables. The performance measured by the LINPACK benchmark consists of the number of 64-bit floating-point operations, generally additions and multiplications, a computer can perform per second, also known as [[FLOPS]]. However, a computer's performance when running actual applications is likely to be far behind the maximal performance it achieves running the appropriate LINPACK benchmark.<ref>{{Citation |title = Jack Dongarra interview by Sander Olson |url = http://nextbigfuture.com/2010/06/jack-dongarra-interview-by-sander-olson.html }}</ref>
The name of these benchmarks comes from the [[LINPACK]] package, a collection of algebra [[Fortran]] subroutines widely used in the 1980s, and initially tightly linked to the LINPACK benchmark. The [[LINPACK]] package has been since then replaced by other libraries.
==History== The LINPACK benchmark report appeared first in 1979 as an appendix to the [[LINPACK]] user's manual.<ref>{{Citation |last1 = Dongarra |first1 = J.J. |last2 = Moler |first2 = C.B. |last3 = Bunch |first3 = J.R. |last4 = Stewart |first4 = G.W. |title = LINPACK: users' guide |year = 1979 |publisher = [[Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics|SIAM]] |url = https://books.google.com/?id=AmSm1n3Vw0cC&lpg=PR5&dq=info%3Ahttp%3A%2F%2Fs3da3171290b34600.scholar.google.com%2F0&pg=SL2-PA1#v=onepage&q&f=false |isbn = 9780898711721 }}</ref>
LINPACK was designed to help users estimate the time required by their systems to solve a problem using the [[LINPACK]] package, by extrapolating the performance results obtained by 23 different computers solving a matrix problem of size 100.
This matrix size was chosen due to memory and CPU limitations at that time:
* 10,000 floating-point entries from -1 to 1 are randomly generated to fill in a general, dense matrix, * then, [[LU decomposition]] with partial pivoting is used for the timing.
Over the years, additional versions with different problem sizes, like matrices of order 300 and 1000, and constraints were released, allowing new optimization opportunities as hardware architectures started to implement matrix-vector and matrix-matrix operations.<ref>{{Citation |last = Dongarra |first = Jack |title = The LINPACK benchmark: An explanation |year = 1988 |journal = Supercomputing |pages = 456–474 |publisher = Springer Berlin/Heidelberg |url = http://www.netlib.org/utk/people/JackDongarra/PAPERS/The-LINPACK-Benchmark-An-Explanation.pdf }}</ref>
Parallel processing was also introduced in the LINPACK Parallel benchmark in the late 1980s.<ref name = "hplpaper">{{Citation |last1 = Dongarra |first1 = Jack J. |last2 = Luszczek |first2 = Piotr |last3 = Petitet |first3 = Antoine |title = The LINPACK Benchmark: past, present and future |year = 2003 |journal = Concurrency and Computation: Practice and Experience |pages = 803–820 |publisher = John Wiley & Sons, Ltd. |url = http://www.netlib.org/utk/people/JackDongarra/PAPERS/hplpaper.pdf }}</ref>
In 1991 the LINPACK was modified for<ref>{{Citation |title = High Performance Linpack Benchmark |accessdate = 2015-02-10 |url = http://icl.cs.utk.edu/graphics/posters/files/SC2010-HPL.pdf }}</ref> solving problems of arbitrary size, enabling [[supercomputer|high performance computers]] (HPC) to get near to their asymptotic performance.
Two years later this benchmark was used for measuring the performance of the first [[TOP500]] list.
==The benchmarks==
===LINPACK 100=== LINPACK 100 is very similar to the original benchmark published in 1979 along with the [https://books.google.com/books?id=AmSm1n3Vw0cC&lpg=PR5&ots=EDFdqJhr8x&dq=info%3Ahttp%3A%2F%2Fs3da3171290b34600.scholar.google.com%2F0&lr&pg=SL2-PA1#v=onepage&q&f=false LINPACK users' manual]. The solution is obtained by [[Gaussian elimination]] with [[pivot element|partial pivoting]], with 2/3n³ + 2n² floating point operations where ''n'' is 100, the order of the dense matrix ''A'' that defines the problem. Its small size and the lack of software flexibility doesn't allow most modern computers to reach their performance limits. However, it can still be useful to predict performances in numerically intensive user written code using compiler optimization.<ref name="hplpaper"/>
===LINPACK 1000=== LINPACK 1000 can provide a performance nearer to the machine's limit because in addition to offering a bigger problem size, a matrix of order 1000, changes in the algorithm are possible. The only constraints are that the relative accuracy can't be reduced and the number of operations will always be considered to be 2/3n³ + 2n², with n = 1000.<ref name="hplpaper"/>
===HPLinpack=== The previous benchmarks are not suitable for testing parallel computers,<ref>{{Citation |url = http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/stamp/stamp.jsp?tp=&arnumber=5348941&isnumber=5348846 |last1 = Bailey |first1 = D.H. |last2 = Barszcz |first2 = E. |last3 = Barton |first3 = J.T. |last4 = Browning |first4 = D.S. |last5 = Carter |first5 = R.L. |last6 = Dagum |first6 = L. |last7 = Fatoohi |first7 = R.A. |last8 = Frederickson |first8 = P.O. |last9 = Lasinski |first9 = T.A. |last10 = Schreiber |first10 = R.S. |last11 = Simon |first11 = H.D. |last12 = Venkatakrishnan |first12 = V. |last13 = Weeratunga |first13 = S.K. |title = The NAS parallel benchmarks summary and preliminary results |journal = Supercomputing |year = 1991 |conference = Supercomputing '91. Proceedings of the 1991 ACM/IEEE Conference |pages = 158–165 }}</ref> and the so-called Linpack's Highly Parallel Computing benchmark, or HPLinpack benchmark, was introduced. In HPLinpack the size n of the problem can be made as large as it is needed to optimize the performance results of the machine. Once again, 2/3n³ + 2n² will be taken as the operation count, with independence of the algorithm used. Use of the [[Strassen algorithm]] is not allowed because it distorts the real execution rate.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.netlib.org/utk/people/JackDongarra/faq-linpack.html#_Can_I_use |title = LINPACK FAQ - Can I use Strassen’s Method when doing the matrix multiples in the HPL benchmark or for the Top500 run? |accessdate = 2015-02-10 }}</ref> The accuracy must be such that the following expression is satisfied:
<math>{\lVert Ax-b\rVert\over \lVert A\rVert \lVert x\rVert n \epsilon} \leq O(1)</math>, where <math>\epsilon</math> is the machine's precision, and ''n'' is the size of the problem,<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.netlib.org/utk/people/JackDongarra/faq-linpack.html#_Toc27885722 |title = LINPACK FAQ - To what accuracy must be the solution conform? |accessdate = 2015-02-10 }}</ref> <math>\lVert \cdot \rVert</math> is the [[matrix norm]] and <math>O(1)</math> corresponds to the [[big-O notation]].
For each computer system, the following quantities are reported:<ref name="hplpaper"/>
* R<sub>max</sub>: the performance in GFLOPS for the largest problem run on a machine. * N<sub>max</sub>: the size of the largest problem run on a machine. * N<sub>1/2</sub>: the size where half the Rmax execution rate is achieved. * R<sub>peak</sub>: the theoretical peak performance GFLOPS for the machine.
These results are used to compile the [[TOP500]] list twice a year, with the world's most powerful computers.<ref name="top500">{{cite web |title = The Linpack Benchmark, TOP500 Supercomputing Sites |url = http://www.top500.org/project/linpack |accessdate = 2015-02-10 }}</ref>
==LINPACK benchmark implementations== The previous section describes the ground rules for the benchmarks. The actual [[implementation]] of the program can diverge, with some examples being available in [[Fortran]],<ref>{{cite web |title = Linpack benchmark program in Fortran |accessdate = 2015-02-10 |url = http://www.netlib.org/benchmark/linpackd }}</ref> [[C (programming language)|C]] <ref>{{cite web|title = Linpack benchmark program in C |accessdate = 2015-02-10 |url = http://www.netlib.org/benchmark/linpackc }}</ref> or [[Java (programming language)|Java]].<ref>{{cite web|title = Linpack benchmark program in Java |accessdate = 2015-02-10 |url = http://www.netlib.org/benchmark/linpackjava }}</ref>
===HPL=== HPL is a portable implementation of HPLinpack that was written in C, originally as a guideline, but that is now widely used to provide data for the TOP500 list, though other technologies and packages can be used. HPL generates a linear system of equations of order n and solves it using LU decomposition with partial row pivoting. It requires installed implementations of [[Message Passing Interface|MPI]] and either [[BLAS]] or [[VSIPL]] to run.<ref>{{cite web|title = HPL - A Portable Implementation of the High-Performance Linpack Benchmark for Distributed-Memory Computers |accessdate = 2015-02-10 |url = http://www.netlib.org/benchmark/hpl }}</ref>
Coarsely, the algorithm has the following characteristics:<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.netlib.org/benchmark/hpl/algorithm.html |title = HPL algorithm }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url = http://icl.cs.utk.edu/hpl/overview/index.html |title = HPL overview |accessdate = 2015-02-10 }}</ref>
* Cyclic data distribution in 2D blocks. * [[LU factorization]] using the right-looking variant with various depths of [[look-ahead (LU factorization)|look-ahead]]. * Recursive panel factorization. * Six different panel [[broadcasting (computing)|broadcasting]] variants. * Bandwidth reducing swap-broadcast algorithm. * Backward substitution with look-ahead of depth 1.
==Criticism== The LINPACK benchmark is said to have succeeded because of the scalability<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.taborcommunications.com/archives/102765.html |archive-url = https://archive.is/20130203094337/http://www.taborcommunications.com/archives/102765.html |dead-url = yes |archive-date = 2013-02-03 |title = An interview with supercomputer legend Jack Dongarra |date = 2012-05-24 }}</ref> of HPLinpack, the fact that it generates a single number, making the results easily comparable and the extensive historical data base it has associated.<ref>{{cite web |quote = LINPACK is a benchmark that people often cite because there’s such a historical data base of information there, because it’s fairly easy to run, it’s fairly easy to understand, and it captures in some sense the best and worst of programming. |title = An interview with Jack J. Dongarra |first = Thomas |last = Haigh |year = 2004 |url = http://history.siam.org/pdfs2/Dongarra_%20returned_SIAM_copy.pdf }}</ref> However, soon after its release, the LINPACK benchmark was criticized for providing performance levels "generally unobtainable by all but a very few programmers who tediously optimize their code for that machine and that machine alone",<ref>{{Citation |last = Hammond |first = Steven |title = Beyond Machoflops: Getting MPPs Into the Production Environment |year = 1995 |url = http://nldr.library.ucar.edu/repository/collections/TECH-NOTE-000-000-000-227 }}</ref> because it only tests the resolution of [[Dense linear system|dense linear systems]], which are not representative of all the operations usually performed in scientific computing.<ref>{{Citation |last1 = Gahvari |first1 = Hormozd |last2 = Hoemmen |first2 = Mark |last3 = Demmel |first3 = James |last4 = Yelick |first4 = Katherine |title = SPEC Benchmark Workshop |contribution = Benchmarking Sparse Matrix-Vector Multiply in Five Minutes |year = 2006 |url = http://bebop.cs.berkeley.edu/pubs/gahvari2007-spmvbench-spec.pdf }}</ref> [[Jack Dongarra]], the main driving force behind the LINPACK benchmarks, said that, while they only emphasize "peak" CPU speed and number of CPUs, not enough stress is given to local bandwidth and the network.<ref>{{Citation |last = Dongarra |first = Jack J. |title = SPEC Benchmark Workshop |year = 2007 |contribution = The HPC Challenge Benchmark: A Candidate for Replacing Linpack in the Top500? |url = http://www.spec.org/workshops/2007/austin/slides/Keynote_Jack_Dongarra.pdf }}</ref>
[[Thom Dunning, Jr.]], director of the [[National Center for Supercomputing Applications]], had this to say about the LINPACK benchmark: "The Linpack benchmark is one of those interesting phenomena -- almost anyone who knows about it will deride its utility. They understand its limitations but it has mindshare because it's the one number we've all bought into over the years."<ref>{{Cite news |url = http://www.technologyreview.com/blog/mimssbits/25981/ | title = Why China's New Supercomputer Is Only Technically the World's Fastest | author = Christopher Mims | date = 2010-11-08 | accessdate = 2011-09-22 }}</ref>
According to Dongarra, "the organizers of the Top500 are actively looking to expand the scope of the benchmark reporting" because "it is important to include more performance characteristic and signatures for a given system".<ref>{{cite web |title = An interview with supercomputing legend jack dongarra |last = Meuer |first = Martin |date = 2002-05-24 |accessdate = 2015-02-10 |url = http://www.taborcommunications.com/archives/102765.html |archive-url = https://archive.is/20130203094337/http://www.taborcommunications.com/archives/102765.html |dead-url = yes |archive-date = 2013-02-03 }}</ref> One of the possibilities that is being considered to extend the benchmark for the TOP500 is the [[HPC Challenge Benchmark]] Suite.<ref>{{Citation |title = Introduction to the HPC Challenge Benchmark Suite |year = 2005 |last1 = Luszczek |first1 = Piotr |last2 = Dongarra |first2 = Jack J. |last3 = Koester |first3 = David |last4 = Rabenseifner |first4 = Rolf |last5 = Lucas |first5 = Bob |last6 = Kepner |first6 = Jeremy |last7 = Mccalpin |first7 = John |last8 = Bailey |first8 = David |last9 = Takahashi |first9 = Daisuke |url = http://icl.cs.utk.edu/projectsfiles/hpcc/pubs/hpcc-challenge-benchmark05.pdf }}</ref> With the advent of [[Petascale computing|petascale computers]], [[traversed edges per second]] have started to emerge as an alternative metric to FLOPS measured by LINPACK. Another alternative is the [[HPCG benchmark]], proposed by Dongarra.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.hpcwire.com/2014/06/26/development-pushes-ahead-new-hpc-benchmark/#|title=New HPC Benchmark Delivers Promising Results|last=Hemsoth|first=Nicole|date=June 26, 2014|publisher=HPCWire|accessdate=2014-09-08}}</ref>
===The running time issue=== According to [[Jack Dongarra]], the running time required to obtain good performance results with HPLinpack is expected to increase. At a conference held in 2010, he said he expects running times of 2.5 days in "a few years".<ref>{{Citation |last = Dongarra |first = Jack J. |conference = International Supercomputing Conference |title = LINPACK Benchmark with Time Limits on Multicore & GPU Based Accelerators |year = 2010 |url = http://www.netlib.org/utk/people/JackDongarra/SLIDES/isc-talk-06102.pdf }}</ref>
==See also== {{Portal|Computer science}} * [[Traversed edges per second]] * [[LAPACK]] * [[LINPACK]] * [[HPCG benchmark]]
{{clear|left}}
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== * [http://www.top500.org/project/linpack/ TOP500 LINPACK] * [http://www.netlib.org/benchmark/linpackjava/ a web-based LINPACK benchmark] * [https://software.intel.com/en-us/articles/intel-math-kernel-library-linpack-download Intel® Optimized LINPACK Benchmark]
[[Category:Benchmarks (computing)]]

[[Image:Saxo Lassenfrag front 001.jpg|thumb|150px|right|Lassen Fragment, Front]] [[Image:Saxo Lassenfrag back 001.jpg|thumb|150px|right|Lassen Fragment, Back]]
The '''Lassen Fragment''', is a [[parchment]] page from c. 1275. It is one of the four fragments remaining of the original, or early copy of, [[Saxo Grammaticus|Saxo]]'s [[Gesta Danorum]]. Size is 40x27 cm. It consists of one page with two written sides.
==History== It was found 1860 in the [[literary remains]] of library-secretary ''G. F. Lassen'', and is now owned by the [[Danish Royal Library|Royal Library]] of [[Copenhagen]]. It has Royal Library signature of ''Ny kgl. Saml. Fol. 570''.
Correspond to page 275-282 in [[Peter Erasmus Müller]] Latin version of ''Gesta Danorum'' from 1839 or page 152.29 – 156.14 in [[Jørgen Olrik]] & H. Ræder's Latin version of ''Gesta Danorum'' from 1931.
==See also== * [[Angers Fragment]] * [[Kall-Rasmussen Fragment]] * [[Plesner Fragment]]
==References== {{reflist}} * ''Apoteker Sibbernsens Saxobog'', C. A. Reitzels Forlag, Copenhagen, 1927.
[[Category:13th-century Latin books]] [[Category:Danish chronicles]] [[Category:13th-century manuscripts]]
{{Denmark-hist-stub}}

page.title: List of W. S. Gilbert dramatic works

revision.comment: No discussion was opened, and if it were, I would oppose the merge. If you wish to template the article with the "merge" template, you need to open a discussion on the Talk page.
revision.text:
The [[dramatist]] and author [[W. S. Gilbert]] wrote approximately 80 dramatic works during his career, as well as light verse, short stories and other works. He is best remembered for his series of 14 libretti for his [[Gilbert and Sullivan|joint operatic works]] with the composer [[Arthur Sullivan]], but many of his other dramatic works were popular successes.Stedman, Jane W. [http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/33400 "Gilbert, Sir William Schwenck (1836–1911)"], ''Oxford Dictionary of National Biography'', Oxford University Press, September 2004, online edition, May 2008, accessed 10 January 2010 {{ODNBsub}} ==List== In the following list, the title of each work appears in the first column, along with any further information (such as the source of an adaptation). The genre appears in the second column, and if the piece had music, the composer's name is listed in parentheses. The theatre and date of first performance appear in the third and fourth columns. All theatres were in London, unless otherwise stated. The works are listed in the approximate order of composition. (In a few cases, the first performance was many years after the work was first published.) {| class="wikitable" |- !Title!!Genre!!Theatre!!Date |- |'''''Uncle Baby''''' |One-Act Comedietta |[[Lyceum Theatre (London)|Lyceum Theatre]] |1863-10-31 |- |'''''Ruy Blas''''' [published in Warne's Christmas Annual, 1866, based on the [[Victor Hugo]] drama, ''[[Ruy Blas]]''.] |[[Victorian burlesque|Burlesque]] |unperformed |N/A |- |'''''Hush-a-Bye, Baby''', on the Tree Top; or, Harlequin Fortunia, King Frog of Frog Island, and the Magic Toys of Lowther Arcade'' [written with Chas. Millard] |[[Pantomime]] |Astley's |nowrap|1866-12-26 |- |'''''[[Dulcamara! or, The Little Duck and the Great Quack]]''''' [parody of [[Gaetano Donizetti|Donizetti]]'s ''[[L'elisir d'amore]]''] |[[Extravaganza]] |[[St. James's Theatre]] |1866-12-29 |- |'''''[[La Vivandière (Gilbert)|La Vivandière'''; or, True to the Corps!]]'' [parody of [[Gaetano Donizetti|Donizetti]]'s ''[[La fille du régiment]]''] |Extravaganza |St. James's Hall, Liverpool |1867-06-15 |- |'''''Robinson Crusoe'''; or, The Injun Bride and the Injured Wife'' [written with [[Henry James Byron|H. J. Byron]], [[Tom Hood]], H. S. Leigh and Arthur Sketchley] |Burlesque |[[Haymarket Theatre|Haymarket]] |1867-07-06 |- |'''''Allow Me To Explain''''' |One-Act [[Farce]] |[[Scala Theatre|Prince of Wales's Theatre]] |1867-11-04 |- |'''''Highly Improbable''''' |One-Act Farce |[[Royalty Theatre]] |1867-12-05 |- |'''''A Colossal Idea''''' [first pub. 1932] |One-Act Farce |unperformed |N/A |- |'''''[[Harlequin Cock Robin and Jenny Wren]]'''; or, Fortunatus and the Water of Life, the Three Bears, the Three Gifts, the Three Wishes, and the Little Man who Woo'd the Little Maid'' |[[Pantomime]] |Lyceum |1867-12-26 |- |'''''[[The Merry Zingara|The Merry Zingara'''; or, The Tipsy Gipsy and the Pipsy Wipsy]]'' [parody of [[Michael Balfe|Balfe]]'s ''[[The Bohemian Girl]]''] |Extravaganza |Royalty |1868-03-21 |- |'''''[[Robert the Devil (Gilbert)|Robert the Devil'''; or, The Nun, the Dun, and the Son of a Gun]]'' [parody of [[Giacomo Meyerbeer|Meyerbeer]]'s ''[[Robert le diable (opera)|Robert le diable]]''] |Extravaganza |[[Gaiety Theatre, London|Gaiety Theatre]] |1868-12-21 |- |'''''[[No Cards]]''''' |One-Act Musical Entertainment ([[Thomas German Reed]]/"Lionel Elliott"?) |[[Gallery of Illustration]] |1869-03-29 |- |'''''[[The Pretty Druidess|The Pretty Druidess'''; or, The Mother, the Maid, and the Mistletoe Bough]]'' [parody of [[Vincenzo Bellini|Bellini]]'s ''[[Norma (opera)|Norma]]''] |Extravaganza |[[Folly Theatre|Charing Cross Theatre]] |1869-06-19 |- |'''''[[An Old Score]]''''' [revived as ''Quits''] |Three-Act Comedy |Gaiety |1869-07-26 |- |'''''[[Ages Ago]]''''' |One-Act Musical Entertainment ([[Frederic Clay]]) |Gallery of Illustration |1869-11-22 |- |'''''A Medical Man''''' [published in [[Clement Scott]]'s ''Drawing-Room Plays''' (1870)] |One-Act Farce |[[St. George's Hall (London)|St. George's Hall]] |1872-10-24 |- |'''''[[The Princess (play)|The Princess]]''''' [based on [[Alfred Tennyson, 1st Baron Tennyson|Tennyson]]'s poem] |Blank-Verse Parody |[[Olympic Theatre]] |1870-01-08 |- |'''''[[The Gentleman in Black]]''''' |Two-Act Musical Play ([[Frederic Clay]]) |Charing Cross |1870-05-26 |- |'''''[[Our Island Home]]''''' |One-Act Musical Entertainment ([[Thomas German Reed]]) |Gallery of Illustration |1870-06-20 |- |'''''[[The Palace of Truth]]''''' |Three-Act Fairy Comedy |Haymarket |1870-11-19 |- |'''''[[Les brigands|The Brigands]]''''' [translated and adapted from ''[[Les brigands]]'' by [[Henri Meilhac|Meilhac]] and [[Ludovic Halévy|Halévy]]; published by Boosey, 1871] |Three-Act Comic Opera ([[Jacques Offenbach]]) |Theatre Royal, Plymouth |1889-09-02 |- |'''''[[Randall's Thumb]]''''' |Three-Act Comedy |[[Royal Court Theatre|Court Theatre]] |1871-01-25 |- |'''''[[A Sensation Novel]]''''' |Musical Entertainment in Three "Volumes" ([[Thomas German Reed]]) |Gallery of Illustration |1871-01-30 |- |'''''[[Creatures of Impulse]]''''' |One-Act Musical Play ([[Alberto Randegger]]) |Court |1871-04-28 |- |'''''Great Expectations''''' [adapted from the [[Charles Dickens|Dickens]] [[Great Expectations|novel]]] |Drama |Court |1871-05-29 |- |'''''On Guard'''''[http://math.boisestate.edu/GaS/other_gilbert/on_guard/on_guard.html Review and libretto of ''On Guard''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081006131937/http://math.boisestate.edu/gas/other_gilbert/on_guard/on_guard.html |date=2008-10-06 }} |Three-Act Melodramatic Comedy |Court |1871-10-28 |- |'''''[[Pygmalion and Galatea (play)|Pygmalion and Galatea]]''''' |Three-Act Fairy Comedy |Haymarket |1871-12-09 |- |'''''[[Thespis (opera)|Thespis]]'''; or, The Gods Grown Old'' |Two-Act Comic Opera ([[Arthur Sullivan]]) |[[Gaiety Theatre, London|Gaiety]] |1871-12-26 |- |'''''[[Happy Arcadia]]''''' |One-Act Musical Entertainment

Tomline, with [[Gilbert Abbott à Beckett|Gilbert à Beckett]]] |Two-Act Burlesque of The Wicked World |Court |1873-03-03 |- |'''''[[The Realm of Joy]]''''' [written as F. page.title: List of jail and prison museums

revision.text:
[[File:Philadelphia's Eastern State Penitentiary, main gate.jpg|thumb|right|175px|[[Eastern State Penitentiary]] in [[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]]]] {{Expand list|date=August 2008}} Museums have been created from many former jails and prisons. Some old jails converted into museums are listed under the original name of the jail, especially if listed on the US [[National Register of Historic Places]]. For example, see [[Old St. Johns County Jail]] in [[St Augustine, Florida]]. Museums with a main purpose not associated with the jail or prison in which they are located are listed separately, below the main list. To use the sortable table, click on the icons at the top of each column to sort that column in alphabetical order; click again for reverse alphabetical order. {| class="wikitable sortable" !| Name !| Location !| State/Province !| Country !| Jail/

Visit Shepton Prison on one of the very popular guided or self-guided heritage tours, alternatively take part in ghost tours, private tours, educational or corporate days, break out of an escape room or take part in one of many events that happen throughout the year. |} ==See also== *[[List of museums in the United States]] [[Category:Lists of museums|Jail Museums]] [[Category:Prison museums|*]]

[[File:Nebishoaib.jpg|thumb|260px|The complex hosting the tomb]] '''Nabi Shu'ayb''' (also [[transliteration|transliterated]] '''Neby Shoaib''' or '''Nabi Shuaib''', meaning "the Prophet Shu'ayb") is a [[Druze]] religious prophet, traditionally identified with the biblical [[Jethro (Bible)|Jethro]], whose possible shrine/tomb is believed to be located near [[Kfar Zeitim]], not far from [[Tiberias]], [[Israel]]. The identification of Shu'ayb with Jethro, however, is a Druze tradition rather than historical fact (see [[Shuaib]]). Prophet shu'ayb is the 14th prophet.
Nabi Shuayb was an object of traditional veneration by Druze through Palestine. The shrine figured down to [[1948 Arab–Israeli War|Israeli-Arab war of 1948]] as a place where Druze took vows (''nidhr'') and made ''[[ziyarat]]'' ("pilgrimages"). After the 1948 war, Israel placed the [[Maqam (shrine)]] under exclusive Druze care.<ref name="Yazbak 237-9" >Mahmoud Yazbak, 'Holy shrines (''maqamat'') in modern Palestine/Israel and the politics of memory,' in Marshall J. Breger, Yitzhak Reiter, Leonard Hammer (eds.),[https://books.google.com/books?id=nROPAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA237 ''Holy Places in the Israeli-Palestinian Conflict: Confrontation and Co-existence,''] Routledge 2010 pp.231-246 p.241.</ref> A central figure in the [[Druze]] religion, the tomb of Nabi [[Shuaib]], has been a site of annual pilgrimage for the Druze for centuries.<ref name="Dana">Dana, Nissim. (2003). ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=2nCWIsyZJxUC&pg=PA28&dq=%22hittin%22+village&lr=#PPA28,M1 ''The Druze in the Middle East: Their Faith, Leadership, Identity and Status,''] [[Sussex Academic Press]], pp. 28–30.</ref> Shrines dedicated to Nabi [[Shuaib]] are common throughout the [[Levant|Greater Syria]] region.<ref name="Firro" >Kais Firro [https://books.google.com/books?id=owhg2R8Ndy8C&pg=PA236&dq=nabi+shu%27ayb&lr= ''The Druzes in the Jewish State: A Brief History,''] BRILL, 1999.</ref>
==History== [[File:PikiWiki Israel 6935 In the holy place of jethro.jpg|thumb|260px|The courtyard of the complex]] [[File:Nabi-shurayb.jpg|thumb|260px|Another courtyard view]]
In [[Druze]] tradition, it is believed that towards the end of his life, [[Shuaib|Shu'ayb]] took refuge in a cave outside [[Hittin]] (a village just west of [[Tiberias]]), where he would die in old age. His followers buried him at the site and placed a tombstone at his grave.<ref name="Dana"/> Another Druze tradition holds that the [[Ayyubid dynasty|Ayyubid]] sultan [[Saladin]] had a dream the night prior to the [[Battle of Hittin]] in which an angel promised him victory on the condition that after the battle, he would ride his horse westward; then, where the horse would stop, the angel said he would find the burial site of Shu'ayb. The tradition holds that when Saladin's dream was realized, the Druze built a shrine for Shu'ayb at the site.
Nabi Shu'ayb has been expanded and renovated over time.<ref name="Dana"/> The older section of the existing structure was built in the 1880s, under the direction of Sheikh Muhanna Tarif, the ''shaykh al-aql'' (Druze spiritual leader) of [[Julis]].<ref>{{cite book|last1=Firro|first1=Kais|title=A History of the Druzes, Volume 1|date=1992|publisher=Brill|page=315|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=usEUXYnYWxAC&pg=PA314&lpg=PA314|isbn=9004094377}}</ref> Sheikh Muhanna summoned an assembly of religious leaders in the community to discuss and collaborate on its construction. A delegation of high-ranking community members traveled to [[Syria]] and [[Lebanon]] in order to collect funds for new construction and renovations and the local Druze of the [[Galilee]] and [[Mount Carmel]] also made considerable contributions.
After [[Israel]]'s establishment in 1948, and the total depopulation of Hittin which had been a predominantly Muslim village, the Druze were granted full custodianship over the tomb, and an additional 100 [[dunam]]s surrounding it. Under the leadership of Sheikh [[Amin Tarif]], the shrine was then renovated and numerous rooms were added for the hosting of pilgrims. The Israeli government also paved the road leading to Nabi Shu'ayb and provided electricity and water infrastructure services there.<ref name="Dana"/>
==Pilgrimage== {{Druze|Holy places}}
[[File:PikiWiki Israel 1336 Druze Scouts צופים דרוזים בקבר יתרו.jpg|thumb|260px|Druze scouts visiting the tomb]] {{further|Ziyarat al-Nabi Shu'ayb}} The first mention of the tomb dates back to the 12th century CE, and the Druze have held religious festivals there for centuries. According to Druze tradition, the imprint of Shuaib's left foot (''da'sa'') can be seen on the grave. Pilgrims visiting the site pour oil into the imprint, and then rub the oil over their body in order to be blessed with good fortune.<ref name="Dana"/>
The Druze customarily had no fixed date for their annual pilgrimage, which generally occurred sometime in the spring. When the Israeli government granted official recognition of the pilgrimage as a Druze religious holiday, the dates were standardized, such that the event now takes place between April 25 and April 28.<ref name="Firro" /> During the festivities, mass celebrations are held at Nabi Shu'aib, and Druze religious leaders gather there for ritual purposes and to discuss religious questions. Prior to Israel's establishment, Druze from [[Syria]] and [[Lebanon]] also used to participate in the festival, but are no longer able to do so today.<ref name="Dana"/>
==See also== *[[Israeli Druze]] *[[Amin Tarif]] *[[Religious significance of the Syrian region]] *[[Ziyarat al-Nabi Shu'ayb]]
==References== {{Commons category}} {{reflist}}

Brunswick, 1972) [https://archive.org/details/orbislatinusode00graegoog Ed. 1861] [http://www.columbia.edu/acis/ets/Graesse/contents.html Ed. 1909] [http://www.bayerische-landesbibliothek-online.de/orbis-latinus Ed. 1972]</ref> '''Pskoŭ''' – {{lang|be|Пскоў}} (Belarusian[[:be:Горад Пскоў|*]]), '''Pskov''' (Azeri[[:az:Pskov|*]], Czech[[:cs:Pskov|*]], Dutch, French, Romanian, Spanish[[:es:Pskov|*]]), '''Pskov''' – {{lang|ru|Псков}} (Bulgarian[[:bg:Псков|*]], Russian[[:ru:Псков|*]],{{listref|KNAB}} Ukrainian[[:uk:Псков|*]]), '''Pskov''' – {{lang|yi|פּסקאָװ}} (Yiddish), '''Pskov''' – {{lang|hy|Պսկով}} (Armenian[[:hy:Պսկով|*]]), '''Pskov''' {{lang|el|Πσκοφ}} (Greek[[:el:Πσκοφ|*]]), '''Ps′kov''' – {{lang|ru|Пьсковъ}} (archaic Russian),{{listref|KNAB}} '''Pskovas''' (Lithuanian[[:lt:Pskovas|*]]),{{listref|KNAB}} '''Psķovi''' – {{lang|ka|ფსკოვი}} (Georgian[[:ka:ფსკოვი|*]]),{{listref|KNAB}} '''Pskow''' (German, Upper Sorbian[[:hsb:Pskow|*]]), '''Psków''' (Polish),{{listref|KNAB}} '''Pszkov''' (Hungarian[[:hu:Pszkov|*]]), '''Pǔsīkēfū''' – {{lang|zh|普斯科夫}} (Mandarin Chinese[[:zh:普斯科夫|*]]), '''Pusukofu''' – {{lang|ja|プスコフ}} (Japanese[[:ja:プスコフ|*]]), '''Vopski liin''' (local Estonian){{listref|KNAB}} |- | [[Puck, Poland|Puck]] |'''Puck''' (Polish), '''Pùck''' (Kashubian), '''Putzig''' (German) |- | [[Pula]] | '''Pola''' (Italian, Romanian, French, German, Dutch), '''Póla''' (Hungarian), '''Polei''' (older German), '''Pula''' (Croatian, Czech, Finnish, German, Portuguese, Serbian, Slovak), '''Pulj''' (Slovene), '''Poła''' (Venetian), '''Puola''' (Istriot), '''Pòlis''' - ''Πόλις'' (Greek) |- | [[Puławy]] | '''Pilev''' - פּילעװ (Yiddish), '''Puławy''' (Polish) '''Pilev''' (English, Spanish), '''Pullno''' (German) |- | [[Pyrzyce]] | '''Pyrzyce''' (Polish), '''Pyritz''' (German) |}
